title: About
text:
I graduated from the University of Michigan in 2021.

I worked in Denver, Colorado for two years before coming to study at Hopkins.

My academic interests are at the intersection of social determinants of health and infectious disease. I am also interested in epidemiological surveillance.

title: Project 1
text:
Due date: November 8 at 11:59pm
The goal of this assignment is to practice some of the skills we have been learning about in class around quarto, command-line, and version control by building and deploying a website. You also are asked to practice with some command-line skills more formally.


Please use this Quarto file (.qmd) and fill in the requested components by adding the URLs pointing to the GitHub repositories and deployed websites. Render this file to a HTML file.
You will push the .qmd file and rendered HTML file to a private GitHub repostory on GitHub classroom. The link to create a private GitHub repository for yourself to complete Project 1 will be posted in CoursePlus (Note: this creates an empty repository. You will need to clone the reopository locally, add your code, and push your code from your local repo to the remote repository on GitHub Classroom when ready). Please show all your code, if relevant to a section.
The TAs will grade the contents in the GitHub repo by cloning the repo and checking for all the things described below.

title: Project 1
section: 1. Create a GitHub repo for your website
text:
1. Create a GitHub repo for your website
Create a new public GitHub repository titled biostat777-intro-<firstname>-<lastname> (where you replace <firstname> with your first name and <lastname> with your last name) in your own personal GitHub account (e.g. https://github.com/<yourgithubusername>/biostat777-intro-<firstname>-<lastname>).

title: Project 1
text:
2. Build a website using Quarto
Create a new project locally within RStudio or VSCode and build a website for yourself. Your website should include the following:

A home/landing page. This is home page that someone will land on your website. At minimum it should include your name, a short summary about yourself (max 2-3 sentences), and a picture of something you enjoy to do for fun (or a picture of yourself if you are comfortable sharing one).
A page titled ‘About’. This page should describe who you are in greater detail. It could include your professional interests and your educational and/or professional background and/or experience. It could also include any personal information you feel conformable sharing on the website.
A data analysis page called ‘Example analysis’. You can pick any dataset you wish you analyze. In this webpage, you will analyze a dataset and summarize the results. The requirements for this webpage are the following:

You must describe what is the question you aim to answer with the data and data analysis.
You must describe who is the intended audience for the data analysis.
You must describe and link to where the original data come from that you chose.
You must include a link to a data dictionary for the data or create one inside the webpage.
Your analysis must include some minimal form of data wrangling with you using at least five different functions from dplyr or tidyr.
Your analysis should include at least three plots with you using at least three different geom_*() functions from ggplot2 (or another package with geom_*() functions).
Plots should have titles, subtitles, captions, and human-understandable axis labels.
At least one plot should using a type of faceting (facet_grid() or facet_wrap()).
Your analysis must include one image or table (not one you created yourself, but one you have saved locally or one from the web).
Your analysis must include at least two different callout blocks.
Your analysis must include a .bib file, which you use to reference at least three unique citations. For example, it could be to a website or paper from where the original data came from or it could be to a paper describing a method you are using to analyze the data.
Your analysis must include the use of at least 1 margin content.
You must summarize your analysis and/or results with a paragraph (4-6 sentences).
At the end of the data analysis, list out each of the functions you used from each of the packages (dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot2) to help the TA with respect to making sure you met all the requirements described above.

title: Project 1
text:
3. Include a README.md file
Your local repository should include a README.md file describing who is the author of the website and a link to the website after it has been deployed. Other things you might include are the technical details for how the website was created and/or deployed.

title: Project 1
text:
4. Deploy your website
Deploy your website e.g. using Quarto Pub, GitHub pages, or Netlify, etc. (Note: Deploying your website to RPubs will not be accepted).

title: Project 1
text:
5. Share your website
Go to the Discussion Board in CoursePlus and write a short post with a link (URL) to your website (and URL to the corresponding GitHub repository) that you created. Also, list the URLs below for the purposes of grading.
As you read the introductions from other folks in the class, feel free to comment/reply using Discussion board.

Link to your GitHub repository: [Delete this text and replace the text with the link to the public GitHub repo you created above for your website]
Link to your deployed website: [Delete this and replace the text with the link to the public deployed website you created above]

title: Example Data Analysis
text:
The goal of my analysis is to the describe the patient population of the Tuberculosis Epidemiologic Studies Consortium cohort. The intended audience of this project are researchers interested in tuberculosis or cohort studies in general.


Link to original dataset


Link to data dictionary


I used ChatGPT to assist in managing errors and debugging.






Note



This data comes from TBESC-II. “TBESC-II focused on strategies and tools to increase diagnosis and treatment of latent TB infection in populations at high risk of TB infection or progression to TB disease.” Other TBESC cycles have different focuses. Learn More




Division of Tuberculosis Elimination; National Center for HIV, Disease Control, and Prevention (n.d.), Christine S Ho (2022), Tracy Ayers (2024)

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(lubridate)

data <- read_delim("Data Analysis/PartA05022024/PartAMain.csv", delim = "|") 

Warning: One or more parsing issues, call `problems()` on your data frame for details,
e.g.:
  dat <- vroom(...)
  problems(dat)


Rows: 22020 Columns: 209
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: "|"
chr    (4): studyid, birth_country, interpret_lang, se_gentype
dbl  (178): d_case_status, d_review_not_tb, gender, enroll_close_contact, en...
lgl   (17): d_annual_salary, rpt_inf, ofx_inf, cyc_inf, oth_inf_meds, d_cxr_...
date  (10): enroll_date, sectiona_date, interview_date, tb_tx_date, naat_col...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

filtered_data <- data %>%
  mutate(enroll_date = as.Date(enroll_date, format = "%Y-%m-%d")) %>%
  mutate(birth_country = recode(birth_country,
                                "USA" = "United States",
                                "MMR" = "Myanmar",
                                "PHL" = "Philippines",
                                "BTN" = "Bhutan",
                                "IRQ" = "Iraq",
                                "MEX" = "Mexico",
                                "NPL" = "Nepal",
                                "SOM" = "Somalia",
                                "HND" = "Honduras",
                                "SLV" = "El Salvador"))

top_countries <- filtered_data %>%
  count(birth_country) %>%
  arrange(desc(n)) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10) 
  
nusb_top_countries_data <- filtered_data %>%
  filter(birth_country %in% top_countries$birth_country, birth_country != "United States")

nusb_top_countries_data <- nusb_top_countries_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(arrived_yr))

daily_counts <- filtered_data %>%
  count(enroll_date)

cumulative_counts <- daily_counts %>%
  arrange(enroll_date) %>%
  mutate(cumulative_enrollment = cumsum(n))


## TBESC Enrollment Over Time
ggplot(cumulative_counts, aes(x = enroll_date, y = cumulative_enrollment)) + geom_line() + labs(title = "Cumulative Enrollment in TBESC Over Time", x = "Enrollment Date", y = "Cumulative Enrollment", subtitle = "This graph shows that enrollment into the TBESC cohort increased over time \nand occurred at discrete study visits.", caption = "Kate Kurlandsky")







## Top Countries of Origin for Latent Tuberculosis in the TBESC
ggplot(top_countries, aes(x = reorder(birth_country, -n), y = n)) + geom_bar(stat = "identity") + labs(title = "Top Countries of Origin for Latent Tuberculosis Patients in the TBESC", x = "Country of Origin", y = "Count", subtitle = "The United States is the most common country of origin of TBESC patients, however the \nmajority of patients have a country of origin other than the United States.", caption = "Kate Kurlandsky") + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle =  45, hjust = 1))







## Histogram of Year of Arrival to the United States in the TBESC Among Foreign-Born
ggplot(nusb_top_countries_data, aes(x = arrived_yr)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 1) + scale_x_continuous(n.breaks = 10) + labs(title = "Histogram of Arrival Year to the United States in the TBESC Among \nForeign-Born", x = "Arrival Year", y = "Count", subtitle = "This graph shows the immigration patterns of patients in TBESC. Patients from countries such \nas El Salvador, Honduras, and Mexico immigrated to the United States semi-consistently \nover the years, while patients from countries like Bhutan, Myanmar, and the Philippines \nimmigrated in more concentrated periods. ", caption = "Kate Kurlandsky") + facet_wrap(~ birth_country) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))














Warning



We can see the way geopolitics trickles down even to the TBESC cohort. Conflicts drive non-refugee and refugee immigration from parts of the world where tuberculosis is much more common.





An Infographic from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention About TB in the United States




Summary
In this analysis, I have briefly described the patient population in the Tuberculosis Epidemiologic Studies Consortium-II. We see that this cohort was enrolled from 2012-2017. The most common country of origin for patients in this cohort is the United States, however the majority of patients were born outside of the United States. This reflects the makeup of tuberculosis cases in the United States broadly. Lastly, we see that the distribution of arrival to the United States among patients in the TBESC differs based on country of origin.


Functions Used

dplyr

read_delim()
mutate()
recode()
count()
arrange()
slice_head()
filter()

ggplot2

geom_line()
geom_bar()
geom_histogram()










References

Christine S Ho, Masahiro Narita, Pei-Jean I Feng. 2022. “Comparison of Three Tests for Latent Tuberculosis Infection in High-Risk People in the USA: An Observational Cohort Study.” The Lancet Infectious Diseases 22 (1).


Division of Tuberculosis Elimination; National Center for HIV, STD, Viral Hepatitis, Tuberculosis Prevention; Centers for Disease Control, and Prevention. n.d. https://www.cdc.gov/tb/research/tbesc.html.


Tracy Ayers, Julia Raykin, Andrew N. Hill. 2024. “Comparison of Tuberculin Skin Testing and Interferon-γ Release Assays in Predicting Tuberculosis Disease.” JAMA Network Open 7 (4).

title: Kate Kurlandsky
text: I am a second-year Master of Science student at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. I enjoy being outside, hiking, and trying out new coffee shops. I’m originally from Southeast Michigan.
